BA Single Honours: Sports Journalism Degrees

Email a friend information about this course
Our degree in Sports Journalism is aimed at those who are passionate about sport and would like to work in the fast developing world of sport journalism.

The course will develop your academic understanding of aspects of sport including: history, culture, psychology, physiology, and sociology. It will also teach you professional journalism skills including writing for print, radio, TV, and the web.

Whilst you might have an interest in a particular activity, you will be encouraged to explore a range of sports and media outlets. You will also start building a portfolio of your sports - related writing, ready for your chosen career in journalism.

The course is taught by staff with a professional track record in journalism.

Leeds Trinity has a strong track record of providing journalism training and we have an excellent reputation in the industry. The course is taught by staff with a professional track record in journalism, and you will benefit from a fully-equipped media centre, including TV and radio studios

• Gain valuable experience as you learn, with periods of professional work placement.
  • Learn transferable media skills using the latest equipment.
  • Close links with media organisations such as the Press Association.
What jobs do Sports Journalism graduates get?

You will probably have a career vocation towards working in the sports media. However, the academic and professional development offered within this degree programme will be useful in whatever career choice you make.

• Critical Issues in Journalism
  • Shorthand and media Production
  • Practical Journalism I
  • Politics I
  • History of Sport
  • Psychology and Sociology of Sport
  • Leisure Contexts and Cultures
  • Professional work placement

• Practical Journalism II
  • Sport, Politics and History
  • Sports Psychology and Coaching
  • Sport and the Media
  • Politics II
  • Media Production II (Video)
  • Radio Broadcasting
  • Professional work placement

• Advanced Reporting Skills
  • Law for Journalists
  • Philosophy and Journalistic Ethics
  • Sport in Society
  • Representing Sport
  • Politics 3
  • Broadcast Journalism (Television)
  • Media production III
  • Radio Production
  • Television Documentary Production

Lectures are combined with a wide range of teaching support in the form of tutorials, seminar groups, workshops, practical work, project work and case studies.

Assessment takes place during and at the end of each module and includes essays, examinations, oral presentations, portfolios, practical files and professional attachment reports.

An important aspect of the degree during Level Two is the six week placement with an external organisation for example, specialist sport publications, a local or national newspaper, local radio or TV. During the attachment you will develop confidence, knowledge and essential practical skills.

Minimum entry requirements apply.

This degree programme does not require qualifications in specific subjects, however, experience in one or more of the following is desirable: sports studies, psychology, media studies.
